critique: This document pertains to the inspection of tax returns by the Senate Committee on the Judiciary for the years 1945 to 1957. It is related to the study and investigation of anti-trust and anti-monopoly laws. There is no direct indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, or social inclusion. The document expands executive power by allowing the inspection of tax returns. It also centralizes authority at the federal level. There is a balanced approach to national security vs. civil liberties. The document promotes government intervention in economic regulation by allowing the inspection of tax returns for anti-trust and anti-monopoly laws.
